name: Red-breasted Goose
description: One of the most strikingly colored goose species. The front of the neck, chest, and cheeks are rufous with white edges. A white stripe runs from the head across the flanks to the rear belly. The back, head, and front belly are coal-black. It has a short black beak and dark gray legs.
spread_note: Breeds in northern Eurasia, winters by the Black Sea, migrating through Greece and Bulgaria.
food_note: Green parts of grasses and herbs, seeds, grains
image_alt: Red-breasted goose, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Body length 43–45 cm; tail length 10–11 cm; wingspan 116–135 cm; weight 1–1.3 kg
reproduction: Females lay 6–7 eggs in a ground nest; incubation lasts 23–25 days.
attractions: They nest in colonies, often near snowy owl or falcon nests, enhancing chick safety.
projects_note: Listed as endangered on the IUCN Red List. Major threats include hunting and loss of suitable breeding grounds.
breeding: We have kept red-breasted geese since 1998, with the first chicks hatching and being raised in 2003.
